The striped pattern on the barrow, created by alternating layers of earth and stone, is a characteristic feature of prehistoric burial mounds. According to researchers from Trinity College Dublin, this ancient Irish elite burial site is one of the locations where they discovered evidence of first-degree incest among the ancient Irish elite, a practice that was also observed among ancient elites in Egypt and South America. The discovery sheds light on the social structure and genetic history of ancient Irish society.

A groundbreaking archaeological discovery in Mongolia has unearthed the world's oldest known evidence of horse veterinary dental care, dating back to the Deer Stone-Khirigsuur culture between 1300-700 B.C. The image shows the skull of a ritually-sacrificed horse from Bayankhongor, central Mongolia, which is part of a study by the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History. The study reveals that nomadic herders were experimenting with equine dentistry, sawing down teeth that were growing out of place and removing baby teeth to alleviate pain and discomfort. This sophisticated understanding of horse anatomy and behavior allowed the Deer Stone-Khirigsuur culture to develop a tradition of care that was centuries ahead of its time, contributing to the spread of people, ideas, and organisms between East and West.
